conclusion: We have a semi-cylindrical transparent body with a refractive index n = 2, radius R, and length L. Parallel light beams enter vertically through the rectangular surface and some light exits through the curved surface. We need to find the area S of that part of the cylindrical surface where the light exits.
The semi-cylinder has a flat rectangular face with dimensions R (height) and L (length), and a curved surface with radius R and length L.

premise: Light enters vertically through the rectangular surface.
conclusion: The rays are perpendicular to the surface and thus do not change direction at the first surface.
The speed of light changes as it enters the material, but the direction remains the same for normal incidence.

premise: Rays travel through the semi-cylinder and reach the curved surface.
conclusion: At the curved surface, the rays will refract again as they exit the material back into the air.
The critical angle θc is given by sin θc = 1/n = 1/2 = 0.5, so θc = 30 degrees.

premise: Some light exits through the curved surface.
conclusion: Consider rays that are incident at angles less than or equal to 30 degrees.

premise: Light enters vertically through the rectangular surface and travels parallel to the axis.
conclusion: Rays hit the curved surface at various angles depending on their position.
Any angle of incidence less than or equal to 30 degrees will allow the light to refract out.

premise: Geometry of the curved surface is a semi-circle with radius R.
conclusion: The illuminated area S is given by S = 2RθL = (π/3)RL.
